Award.AwardTitle: Silicon Nanowire High-Frequency Field-Effect Transistors - Novel Device Designs and Characterization Techniques

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This project will address the two important aspects of NW FETs - device designs and characterization techniques, with a goal to demonstrate the operation of SiNW FETs in the 1 ? 4 GHz range. Nanowire based HF transistors operating in this range could have transformative impacts in the fields of flexible/wearable/implantable electronics, medical diagnostics/imaging, remote sensing, micro-RFID, etc. The adopted research methodology is general enough to be relevant for different nanowire material systems. This study for the first time would address the fundamental question ? can we get high-speed devices using SiNWs grown by bottom-up methods? Similarly, this study will investigate the effect of various novel NW device designs on their HF performances.

Broader Impact: Successful completion of this project will advance our understanding of the fundamental high-frequency operating limits of SiNW transistors. The nature of the proposed research is such that the knowledge gained from it can be readily incorporated into graduate level curriculum. The PIs have planned to introduce two small course modules: 1) Fabrication of Nanowire Transistors for the course ENEE 719A -Advanced Topics in Microelectronics: Nanostructure Fabrication Technology and 2) Device Physics of Nanowire Transistors for the course ENEE 601 -Semiconductor Devices & Technology. These two modules will expose the students to the latest research results in nanoscale semiconductor devices while broadly disseminating the knowledge gained from the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop high frequency silicon nanowire transistors using material and device innovations. This project involved growth of silicon nanowires utilizing catalyst-assisted vapor liquid solid growth, with emphasis on understanding the role of catalyst in unintentional impurity incorporation in nanowires and their subsequent effect on the device performance. Designing nanowire based high-frequency transistors needed  the understanding of the defects (both surface and bulk) in nanowires, transport properties, and effect of various device configurations on the performance. The project was focused on developing nanomaterials and structures, characterization, device design and fabrication, and testing and modeling. The emphasis of this project was to evaluate the feasibility of implementing VLS grown Si nanowires in a RF device layout and estimate their performance limitation. A major finding of this resarch was that the catalyst used in typical growth methods of these nanostructures produced deep-level traps in the bandgap of these nanostructures, which caused increased levels of noise in the devices.

This information was obtained through a very sensitive noise spectroscopy methods implemented in the project, called cross-correlation method, which has also been successfully used in other novel low-dimensional materials.

 

During the course of last 3 years we have trained 4 PhD students through this program on various aspects of nanomaterials development. We have been able to train them in class 100 cleanroom on state-of-the-art micro and nanofabrication facilities. In addition, 2 senior level scientists were also involved in the project. This allowed them to expand their knowledge base to include the silicon nanowire research. Before this program, both these individual had very little exposure to nanowire related research. This research also allowed us to initiate various national and international collaborations that involved other researchers in related fields.

This project truly represented collaborative ecosystem between academic researchers and federal scientist, with opportunity for students and post-docs to be trained in the tools and methods of nanoscale science and engineering.
